titleStmt.title: Joseph Ricketts et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG5551

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: To His Excellency Tho. E. Bramlett Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Your Petitioners would most respectfuly represent unto your Excellency that at the September Term 1860 of the McLean Circuit Court Stephen Duval was convicted of the Murder of George Johnson a free man of color and sentenced to be hung, but upon satisfactory representations being made to Governor Magoffin his punishment was Commuted to Confinement in the State Penitentiary for life and he has been in Confinement in the Penitentiary since November 1860 Your Petitioners are informed that since his Confinement he has principally been employed in working in hemp & from that is some other cause his health has become very bad & if he is confined longer in the prison he can not live long and believing that he has already suffered sufficiently for his Offence they would most respectfully & humbly Petition your Excellency for his release. They would remark that his mother is a poor widow and an honest Clever woman She hs furnished two sons to the Federal army one of whom has already given his life to his Country and the other is yet a soldier in the 11th Ky and she has but one small boy left to assist her

Joseph Ricketts
Charles Eaves
John Napinger
Jesse Peavler
